Sun of Faith - English: Chapter 28: The First Turning of the Wheel
Then he went to Varanasi.
Manual - Tibetan (བོད་ཡིག།): དེ་ནས་ཝ་ར་ནཱ་སིའི་ཕྱོགས་ལ་དྲང་གྲོང་ལྷུང་བ་རི་དྭགས་ཀྱི་ནགས་ཏེ། རི་ཆུང་ལ་ནགས་ཡོད་པ་ཞིག་ཏུ། འཁོར་ལྔ་སྡེ་ཀུན་ཏུ་རྒྱུའི་ཆ་བྱད་ཅན་རྣམས་ཀྱི་སངས་རྒྱས་རྒྱང་རིང་པོ་ནས་འབྱོན་པ་ལྟ་ཞིང། ཕན་ཚུན་དུ་གཏམ་སྨྲ་བའི་ཚུལ་དང་། འཁྲིས་སུ་བྱོན་པ་ན། གཅིག་གི་གདན་གདིང་།  གཅིག་གི་ཞུ་བ་ཞུ། གཅིག་གི་ཞབས་བཀྲུ། གཅིག་གིས་བསུ་བ་བྱེད། གཅིག་གིས་ཕྱག་འཚལ་ཞིང་། ན་བཟའ་འཁུར་བའི་ཚུལ་བྱེད། དེ་ནས་ཕྱོགས་གཅིག་ཏུ་ཕ་བོང་འདྲ་བ་ཞིག་གི་སྟེང་དུ་སྟོན་པ་བཞུགས་ཤིང་། ལྔ་སྡེ་དགེ་སློང་གི་རྣམ་པ་ཅན་གྱི་ཆོས་ཉན་པའི་ཚུལ་དང་། གཡས་གཡོན་དང་ནམ་མཁའ་ནས་ལྷ་ཆོས་ཉན་པའི་ཚུལ་མང་དུ་བྱ། ཡང་ཕྱོགས་གཅིག་ཏུ། སྟོན་པའི་དྲུང་དུ་དགེ་སློང་གསུམ་འདུག་ཅིང་། དགེ་སློང་གཉིས་ཀྱི་གྲོང་ཁྱེར་ནས་བསོད་སྙོམས་ལེན་པའི་ཚུལ་དང་། ཡང་དེ་དང་ཉེ་བ་ན།
Manual - English: In a small forest, (drang srong lhung ba ri dwags kyi nags), near Varanisi, the five disciples wait and see the Buddha in the distance coming towards them. When the Buddha arrives, one disciple greets, one spreads the mattress, one reports to him, one washes his feet, one prostrates and carries his shawl. the Buddha sits on a boulder and teaches dharma to the five disciples as in the form of fully ordained monks.  Gods from above and gods on the left and right sides listen to the Buddha teaching dharma. Three monks visit the Buddha while two monks beg for alms in the city.

Sun of Faith - English: At that time the group of five [ascetics] were dwelling in Mṛgadāvarṣipatana.
Seeing the Thus Gone One coming from a long way off, they resolved among themselves,
“the one called Gotama, the decadent, is coming.
Don’t speak to him. Don’t pay reverence to him. Don’t rise for him. Don’t give him a seat.
When the Buddha approached them they could not bear his splendor.
All arose and offered reverence to him.
One prepared a seat.
One went to him and took his robe.
One bathed his feet.
“Learned Gautama has come, Good!
“Please rest on the seat we have prepared,” they said.
At this the Buddha instructed that they should not call the Thus Gone One “Venerable” or by [his] family name.
Then they said the following. “Before, when you practiced austerities, you did not change one bit.
And now, you are not firm [in your practice], you indulge in activities, eating, and so forth.”
Buddha said, “Monks, can't you see that my faculties, my brilliance, have changed from before?
I have gained the essence.
Monks, renunciants must not rely on these two extremes: the extreme of overindulgence in what is desired, and the extreme of undergoing extreme hardship and penance.
They must rely on the middle path.
That moreover is the noble eightfold path."
Then in the morning [the Buddha] gave teachings to two of the five monks while three went to collect alms.
They collected alms, and fed the six of them, including the Buddha.
In the afternoon the other three heard the teachings, while two went to collect alms. They collected alms, which fed the five monks.
The Tathagata did not take food in the afternoon.
During that time [the Buddha] first taught the four truths, reciting them three times each for a total of twelve times.
Therefore,Ājñātakauṇḍinya and 80,000 beheld the truth.
After this [the Buddha asked] Kauṇḍinya, “Kauṇḍinya, do you completely understand the Dharma?”
[Kauṇḍinya] said, “Bhagavan, I understand completely.”
[The Buddha] asked this again and again, and thus [Kauṇḍinya] became known as Ājñātakauṇḍinya, “All-knowing” Kauṇḍinya.
At that time, from the land of the divine yakṣas to the furthest limits of the god realm,
a joyful chorus resounded, “The wheel of Dharma has been turned. The divine increases, the infernal decreases. All beings rejoice.”
The Tathagata also taught to the group of five a second teaching connected to the four noble truths, this time from the perspective of an alternative enumeration.
Through this, Kauṇḍinya attained arhatship, while Aśvajit, Bāṣpa, Mahānāman, and Bhadrika beheld the truth.
Then there were two arhats: The Buddha and Kaundinya.
Then [the Buddha] turned the wheel of Dharma starting with selflessness, and the other four monks achieved arhatship.
Then there were six arhats.
